questions.question_text: Which of the following is a responsibility of an Architecture Board?

choices.A: Creating the Statement of Architecture Work
choices.D: Establishing targets for re-use of components
choices.E: Conducting assessments of the maturity level of architecture discipline within the organization
choices.C: Identifying the Lead Enterprise Architect to manage an architecture compliance review

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
list of responsibilities of the Architecture Board with titles only:

Providing Architecture Governance
Setting Architecture Standards
Promoting Re-use
Reviewing and Approving Architectures
Providing Strategic Direction
Guiding and Supporting Architecture Projects
Assessing Architecture Maturity
Managing Risks
Facilitating Communication and Collaboration

Selected Answer: D
This responsibility is outlined in Part VI, Chapter 44: Architecture Board, in the TOGAF 9.2 standard, where the role of the Architecture Board in setting and promoting architecture governance practices, including component re-use, is described.

Selected Answer: D
41.2 Responsibilities
The Architecture Board is typically made responsible, and accountable, for achieving some or all of the following goals:
* Providing the basis for all decision-making with regard to the architectures
* Consistency between sub-architectures
* Establishing targets for re-use of components

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/m/chap41.html

Selected Answer: D
D. Establishing targets for re-use of components

Selected Answer: D
Wording is important. Maturity Assessment is typically conducted by third party organizations. The outcomes from the maturity assessment are considered by the architecture board to improve the organization architecture capabilities and practice.

Correct Answer 


41.2 Responsibilities
The Architecture Board is typically made responsible, and accountable, for achieving some or all of the following goals:

Providing the basis for all decision-making with regard to the architectures
Consistency between sub-architectures
Establishing targets for re-use of components
Flexibility of the Enterprise Architecture:
To meet changing business needs
To leverage new technologies
Enforcement of Architecture Compliance
Improving the maturity level of architecture discipline within the organization
Ensuring that the discipline of architecture-based development is adopted
Supporting a visible escalation capability for out-of-bounds decisions

comments.content: Correct Answer ---- D (Establishing targets for re-use of components)

discussion.content:
D: Correct
E - incorrect.
https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap41.html#tag_41_02
its about 'improving' - not conducing assessment.
Improving the maturity level of architecture discipline within the organization

Both D, E is correct. 
- Improving the maturity level of architecture discipline within the organization
- Establishing targets for re-use of components.
But the exact match is D. 
Link: https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap41.html
Correct Answer is D

Selected Answer: C
It addresses common, reusable elements and reflects general computing requirements across a wide range of uses.

Reference:
This is described in Part V, Chapter 41: Foundation Architecture, in the TOGAF 9.2 standard, where it is outlined as the most generic layer in the Enterprise Continuum, providing reusable architectural components and standards.

Selected Answer: C
Foundation Architecture
* 
* Reflects general computing requirements
* Reflects general building blocks
* Defines technology standards for implementing these building blocks

http://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf8-doc/arch/chap18.html

Correct Answer 

Probably question belongs to TOGAF8
Not found in TOGAF9.2

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of architecture defines technology standards for building blocks and reflects general computing requirements?
What does the TOGAF standard provide to guide architectural activity within the enterprise in terms of structures, roles, responsibilities, and processes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It includes definitions of structures, roles, responsibilities, and processes to support and govern architectural activity effectively.

Reference:
This is covered in Part VI: Architecture Capability Framework, which discusses the organizational capability required to successfully manage and sustain architectural activities within the enterprise.

Selected Answer: B
PART VII
(Architecture Capability Framework) This part discusses the organization, processes, skills, roles, and responsibilities required to establish and operate an architecture function within an enterprise.

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf91-doc/arch/chap01.html

Selected Answer: B
.... terms of structures, roles,

Correct Answer 

39.1 Overview
In order to successfully operate an architecture function within an enterprise, it is necessary to put in place appropriate organization structures, processes, roles, responsibilities, and skills to realize the Architecture Capability

choices.B: To define the scope, identifying stakeholders and obtaining approvals
choices.E: To perform architectural oversight for the implementation
choices.D: To manage requirements throughout the ADM
choices.A: To define the initial implementation plans

discussion.content: Answer A is correct. "Formulate Implementation and Migration Strategy"

Selected Answer: A
12. Phase E: Opportunities & Solutions
12.5 Approach
Phase E is the initial step on the creation of the Implementation and Migration Plan which is completed in Phase F. It provides the basis of a well considered Implementation and Migration Plan that is integrated into the enterprise's portfolio in Phase F.

Selected Answer: A
Objectives
The objectives of Phase E are to:

Evaluate and select among the implementation options identified in the development of the various Target Architectures (for example, build versus buy versus re-use options, and sub-options within those major options)
Identify the strategic parameters for change, and the top-level work packages or projects to be undertaken in moving from the current environment to the target
Assess the dependencies, costs, and benefits of the various projects
Generate an overall implementation and migration strategy and a detailed Implementation Plan

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf8-doc/arch/chap11.html#:~:text=The%20objectives%20of%20Phase%20E,options%20within%20those%20major%20options)

Selected Answer: A
Correct Answer 

Phase E concentrates on how to deliver the architecture. It takes into account the complete set of gaps between the Target and Baseline Architectures in all architecture domains, and logically groups changes into work packages within the enterprise's portfolios. This is an effort to build a best-fit roadmap that is based upon the stakeholder requirements, the enterprise's business transformation readiness, identified opportunities and solutions, and identified implementation constraints. The key is to focus on the final target while realizing incremental business value.

Phase E is the initial step on the creation of the Implementation and Migration Plan which is completed in Phase F. It provides the basis of a well considered Implementation and Migration Plan that is integrated into the enterprise's portfolio in Phase F.
The following four concepts are key to transitioning from developing to delivering a Target Architecture:

Architecture Roadmap
Work Packages
Transition Architectures
Implementation and Migration Plan

Selected Answer: A
https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/index.html
All activities that have been initiated in these steps must be closed during the Create the Architecture Roadmap & Implementation and Migration Plan step

questions.question_text: Which one of the following best describes the purpose of ADM Phase E?
Complete the sentence. Actions arising from the Business Transformation Readiness Assessment technique should be incorporated in the ___________

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
This is described in Part III, Chapter 26: Business Transformation Readiness Assessment, where it highlights the alignment of readiness actions with the migration and implementation activities outlined in the Implementation and Migration Plan.

Selected Answer: D
The Business Transformation Readiness Assessment is used to evaluate an organization's preparedness for implementing architecture changes and executing a transformation. The actions identified from this assessment, such as addressing gaps in readiness, overcoming resistance to change, and building necessary capabilities, are critical for the success of the transformation.

These actions are directly relevant to the Implementation and Migration Plan, as this plan outlines how the architecture will be implemented, including the necessary steps to address organizational readiness, mitigate risks, and ensure a smooth transition.

Selected Answer: D
30.1 Introduction

Understanding the readiness of the organization to accept change, identifying the issues, and then dealing with them in the Implementation and Migration Plans is key to successful architecture transformation in Phases E and F

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf91-doc/arch/chap30.html

Correct Answer 

26.1 Introduction
The recommended activities in an assessment of an organization's readiness to address business transformation are:

Determine the readiness factors that will impact the organization
Present the readiness factors using maturity models
Assess the readiness factors, including determination of readiness factor ratings
Assess the risks for each readiness factor and identify improvement actions to mitigate the risk
Work these actions into Phase E and F Implementation and Migration Plan
